question_details.query: What is the most cost-effective method for reducing lethal vessel strikes on large whales?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two studies reported that setting and enforcing vessel speed limits reduced deaths from collisions: a before-and-after study in the Indian River estuarine system (USA) reported fewer manatee deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas, and a before-and-after study in the North Atlantic Ocean (USA) found fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths during periods with speed limits in key habitats [2777]. No studies were found evaluating the effects of diverting shipping routes [2754], using onboard observers to detect mammals and alter course or speed [2755], or using remote tools to detect mammals and alter course or speed [2757]. The action documents do not report cost or cost-effectiveness data for these methods [2754; 2755; 2757; 2777].
summary_statements: Two studies reported that setting and enforcing vessel speed limits reduced deaths from collisions.
A before-and-after study in the Indian River estuarine system (USA) reported fewer manatee deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas.
A before-and-after study in the North Atlantic Ocean (USA) found fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths during periods with speed limits in key habitats.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of diverting shipping routes.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of using onboard observers to detect mammals and alter course or speed.
No studies were found evaluating the effects of using remote tools to detect mammals and alter course or speed.
The action documents do not report cost or cost-effectiveness data for methods to reduce lethal vessel strikes on large whales.

question_details.query: What is the long-term impact of climate change on the effectiveness of legally protected marine areas for cetaceans?
Which type of public education campaign is most successful at reducing plastic litter ingestion by river dolphins in South America?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No action documents reported evidence on public education campaigns reducing plastic litter ingestion by river dolphins in South America. The available evidence on education for marine and freshwater mammals showed only changes in participant intentions and behaviors—such as increased willingness to support marine conservation or to cut fishing nets to save entangled dolphins, including in Peru—and reported no population or health outcomes (community response: 0 studies; population response: 0 studies) (action 2935). Additional education programme evidence concerned terrestrial carnivores in South Africa and household outreach on garbage and bears in the USA, not dolphins or plastic ingestion outcomes (action 2423). A review from North America stated education alone was not sufficient to change behavior without complementary measures, and did not provide outcomes for dolphins or plastic ingestion (action 162).
summary_statements: No action documents reported evidence on public education campaigns reducing plastic litter ingestion by river dolphins in South America.
The available evidence on education for marine and freshwater mammals showed only changes in participant intentions and behaviors.
Changes in participant intentions and behaviors included an increased willingness to support marine conservation.
Changes in participant intentions and behaviors included an increased willingness to cut fishing nets to save entangled dolphins in Peru.
Available evidence on education for marine and freshwater mammals reported no population or health outcomes.
Additional education programme evidence concerned terrestrial carnivores in South Africa.
Additional education programme evidence concerned household outreach on garbage and bears in the USA.
Additional education programme evidence did not concern dolphins or plastic ingestion outcomes.
A review from North America stated education alone was not sufficient to change behavior without complementary measures.
The review from North America did not provide outcomes for dolphins or plastic ingestion.
